intro: Argemone intermedia subsp. corymbosa, commonly known as the Mexican buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its yellow-orange flowers and palmate leaves, which are typically lobed and hairy. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous seeds, which are dispersed by wind. It thrives in dry, disturbed soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Botanically, it belongs to the family Euphorbiaceae, which includes many species with milky sap.
